body.p:
Bowling Green Kentucky
6th August 1864
Gov Bramlette
Frankfort Ky.
Dear Sir

A Judgment for a forfeiture of One Thousand and fifty dollars, has been rendered by the Warren Circuit Court at its present term against Levi Moore for engaging in the business of a Broker, and exchange dealer without having obtained license as required by. law,

Mr Moore was a broker while the rebel Army Occupied this Section of Country, and the circumstances attending his case are precisely such as those attending the case of H P Allen about which I addressed you a day or two Since. The court in his opinion and Judgt in the Moore case says it is a case for the interposition of the executive I am of the Same opinion, and believe you should remit the forfeiture, to the extent of your Constitutional power, as an act of Clemency & Justice to Mr Moore,

Respectfully
Wm B Jones atty for the Comth

From ^the proof^ in the Case and my own knowledge of the condition of affairs in Bowlinggreen, during its occupation by the rebel troops I do not hesitate ^to unite^ in asking from the Governor that Mr Moore be released as far as may be in his power
This is a less aggravated case than H P Allen, (whose papers are already laid before you) and is entitled as we think to your favorable consideration --
The brokers and bankers were a useful class whilst the Rebels were in this place -- and under the Circumstances we urgently ask You to release mr Levi Moore as far as You have the power to do so --

B, C, Grider
R Rodes
J C Wilkins
Wm V. Loving
J. E. Halsell
L L Cooke Clerk Warren circuit court --
H. V. Loving
James H. Rose
W H Payne

Warren Cir Ct
vs
Levi Moore
$1050.
Remit
8th Aug'/64
